awd_titl_txt: Enzyme-Inspired Catalysis in Multifunctional Metal-Organic Framework Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is addressing the synthesis of catalysts with designs inspired by enzymes, Nature's premier catalysts. Enzymes catalyze reactions up to a million times faster than synthetic catalysts. Moreover, they do so with unparalleled selectivity, producing only the desired product. If industrial catalysts performed as well as enzymes, then commercial reactions could be conducted with greatly reduced energy costs and waste generation. With this motivation, Dr. Gadzikwa and her research group at Kansas State University are developing enzyme-inspired catalysts for the efficient conversion of petroleum raw materials into chemical feedstocks for the pharmaceutical industry. A significant portion of the work in this project is being conducted by novice researchers. The Gadzikwa lab is thus providing valuable laboratory research experience for undergraduates. Dr Gadzikwa is enhancing the participation of underrepresented groups in science by engaging first-generation and underrepresented minority students. Outreach to the public is being made by facilitating activities for elementary school children at the Flint Hills Discovery Center, for middle-schoolers through the KState Girls Researching Our World (GROW) program, and for high school students at the KState Annual Chemistry & Physics Symposium.

Chiral amines, frequently occurring constituents of biologically active molecules, are currently accessed via an inefficient 3-step industrial process. These valuable products could potentially be obtained more efficiently via the hydroamination of unfunctionalized internal alkenes, which are produced on a large scale via petrochemical processes. Unfortunately, the reactions of these so-called unbiased olefins are prohibitively too slow and indiscriminate to undertake industrially. To address these problems, Dr. Gadzikwa's lab is co-opting the strategies of enzymes and transferring them onto the solid-state scaffold of metal-organic framework (MOF) materials. This work is motivated by the hypothesis that the combination of three of the most distinguishing characteristics of enzymes - (i) catalytic sites isolated within shape-selective, confined spaces, (ii) side chains within the cavities that promote and direct the reaction, and (iii) flexibility that allows the cavity to strongly bind all species in the reaction pathway - will result in solid-state catalysts whose activities and selectivities will finally render the reactions of unbiased olefins industrially feasible. This project involves MOF synthesis and functionalization, both of which are amenable to the busy schedules of undergraduate researchers. The Gadzikwa lab draws students from the Kansas Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (KS-LSAMP) and the KState Developing Scholars Program for first generation university students. The Gadzikwa lab also seeks to broaden participation via public outreach, routinely participating in activities to promote Chemistry to Kansas' K-12 students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Fine chemical manufacturing is a fast-growing, $85 billion industry whose products are found in pharmaceuticals, food products, and agrichemicals. Because their usage is so closely tied to human health and consumption, these chemicals need to be produced in highly pure forms via costly, multi-step, small-batch syntheses. With the chemical industry’s increasing focus on sustainability, the need for processes that reduce waste and energy consumption is also growing. Selective catalysis satisfies these goals by reducing reaction times, waste products, and the number of purification processes required. Heterogeneous (solid-state) catalysts are also attractive as they have the advantages of increased stability, ease of separation, and recyclability. For fine chemical catalysis, however, a choice must be made between the selectivity of homogeneous (solution-phase) systems and the simpler industrial processes that are made possible by solid-state catalysis.

To avoid this undesirable choice, we proposed the synthesis and application of selective heterogeneous catalysts inspired by enzymes, Nature’s most efficient and selective catalysts. The project entailed the functionalization of porous, crystalline materials, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), to generate enzyme-inspired catalysts for use in selective catalyzed transformations. The goal was driven by the hypothesis that the assembly of materials that possess three of the most distinguishing characteristics of enzymes – catalytic active sites isolated within confined spaces, side chains within the cavities that promote and direct the reaction, and flexibility that allows the cavity to strongly bind both the substrate and the transition state – would result in solid-state catalysts with superior activities and selectivities compared to their homogeneous counterparts.

To this end, we synthesized several MOF materials with large pores, and put forward a hypothesis for a general strategy of synthesizing such materials. Subsequently, we demonstrated multiple methodologies for their modification to produce cavities that are identically decorated with multiple distinct functionalities. Interestingly, we demonstrated that, when immobilized together in confined space, some chemical functionalities can influence each other’s reactivity in unexpected ways. This behavior was encouraging as it is reminiscent of the way that functional groups in enzymes cavities sometimes perturb each other’s physical properties. Finally, we synthesized a series of catalytic MOF materials where we modulated their activity by systematically altering the chemical environment of their cavities.

Intellectual merit: we have contributed, and continue to add, evidence to support hypotheses surrounding the construction of some large-pore framework materials. We have also used such frameworks to generate confined spaces that are uniformly decorated with multiple distinct functionalities – an otherwise daunting synthetic task. We have also reported that immobilizing two different chemical functionalities together in MOF pores can lead to confinement effects that result in unexpected reactivity. To the best of our knowledge, aside from enzymes, we have the only example of chemical functionalities reversing their relative reactivity upon mutual confinement. More recently, in unpublished results, we have found that modifying the chemical environment of catalysts immobilized in MOF cavities can significantly increase catalytic activity.

Broader impact: The uniform MOF functionalization strategy we developed lets us, and others, precisely organize distinct functionality in MOF pores, allowing for the construction of multifunctionalized materials capable of performing cooperative or multi-action processes in confined spaces. This ability is crucial for the generation of bio-inspired materials that can mimic the behaviors of enzymes. We anticipate that such materials would have significantly improved catalytic activities and selectivities. This would be an important outcome for the fine-chemical industry (pharmaceutical, agrochemical, and specialty chemical), which would see greatly reduced reaction times, energy costs, and generated waste. In the long-term, as more insight is gained and more sophisticated materials are constructed, we envision performing, with competencies that begin to approach those of enzymes, some of Nature’s most important transformations: e.g., energy production, atmospheric purification, small-molecule activation.

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2022
Modified by: Tendai Gadzikwa
